definitions.definition: to stop doing something or making something because it is complete
definitions.sensetop: finish (something)finish what…finish doing somethingfinish by doing something+ speech

examples.text: Haven't you finished your homework yet?
She finished law school last year.
You only get points if you finish the race.
I thought you'd never finish!
We've **just finished** the project.
Let me **just finish** what I'm doing.
Be quiet! He hasn't finished speaking.
He finished by telling us about his trip to Spain.
‘And that was all,’ she finished.
‘I had no idea…’ I finished lamely.
She had just finished dressing when her phone rang.
Peter finished Jane's sentence for her.
I’ll just finish the chapter then I’ll come.

definitions.definition: to come to an end; to bring something to an end

examples.text: The play finished at 10.30.
The symphony finishes with a flourish.
The evening finished with a few songs.
A cup of coffee finished the meal perfectly.

definitions.definition: to eat, drink or use what remains of something
definitions.sensetop: finish somethingfinish something offfinish something up

examples.text: I quickly finished my tea.
He finished off his drink with one large gulp.
We might as well finish up the cake.
We might as well finish up the cake—there isn't much left.
We'll go out after you've finished your dinner.

definitions.definition: to be in a particular state or position at the end of a race or a competition
definitions.sensetop: + adj.+ adv./prep.finish something + adv./prep.finish something + adj.

examples.text: She was delighted to finish second.
He finished 12 seconds outside the world record.
The team finished the season in ninth position.
The dollar finished the day slightly down.

definitions.definition: to make somebody so tired or impatient that they cannot do any more

examples.text: Climbing that hill really finished me off.
A lecture from my parents now would just finish me.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French feniss-, lengthened stem of fenir, from Latin finire, from finis ‘end’.
